Award.AwardTitle: An Interatomic Potential for LixSi Alloys and Its Applications to Lithiation Induced Deformation and Failure in Silicon

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of this project are (1) to obtain an interatomic potential for LixSi Alloys and (2) to use this interatomic potential to study the lithiation induced deformation and failure of silicon anode in lithium-ion batteries. Making solar energy economical and providing energy from fusion are two of the grand challenges identified by the National Academy of Engineering. A key component of both challenges is energy storage. At the moment, the most economical and efficient way of storing solar energy is electrical battery. Lithium-ion battery is considered the most promising technology for high density energy storage, and silicon is the highest capacity anode material. Despite the rapid development and significant progress made in recent years, capacity degradation and short lifetime have not been solved for silicon based anodes. Among other things, the lack of understanding of the mechanisms for lithium insertion/extraction, and the lack of efficient tools for designing Si-based anodes are the major roadblocks that prevent the technology breakthroughs for commercialization.

To meet the above needs, this project is (1) to obtain an interatomic potential for LixSi Alloys and (2) to use this interatomic potential to study the deformation and failure of silicon anode in lithium ion batteries. Such an interatomic potential for LixSi alloys will be a powerful tool. It enables us to validate the various continuum models on lithium insertion. It can be used to estimate some of the material properties that are difficult to obtain experimentally. It gives us a mean to study the microstructural mechanisms of fracture and failure. Besides contributing to science and engineering, the research activities will also have a broader impact on educating students by (1) integrating the research results into a core engineering course, "Multi-scale Modeling", (2) recruiting undergraduates for research, focusing on women and minorities, (3) providing a platform for cross-department interactions among graduate students, and (4) recruiting local high school teachers and students for summer research experience in the PI's lab.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Making solar energy economical and providing energy from fusion are two of the grand challenges identified by the National Academy of Engineering.  A key component of both challenges is energy storage.  At the moment, the most economical and efficient way of storing solar energy is electrical battery.

Li-ion battery is considered the most promising technology for high density energy storage. A key factor limiting the energy storage capacity of Li-ion batteries is the capacities of the anode to store Li ions.  In most commercial Li-ion batteries today, the anode is made of graphite, which has a capacity of 370 mAh/g.  Silicon (Si) on the other hand has a much higher capacity (> 3500 mAh/g). In other words, Si anode could potentially increase the battery capacity by an order of magnitude, which would be a revolutionary breakthrough in battery technology. However, the volume of Si increases by almost 400% when Li ions are inserted into its crystalline structure.  Such huge volume expansion often fractures the anode leading to reduced battery capacity and lifetime.

This project is aimed at (1) understanding the process of charging and discharging in Li-ion batteries with Si anode, and (2) developing models that can assist us designing higher capacity and more durable batteries. To achieve these goals, the project developed and experimentally validated a theory that is capable of describing the electrochemical process of Li insertion into and extraction from Si. This new theory was then used to simulate the process of Li insertion into Si anode. Based on the simulation results, the project developed design guidelines for higher capacity and more durable silicon-based anode in Li-ion batteries.

In addition, the theoretical models developed in this project advanced our fundamental knowledge of solid-state diffusion and transport in stressed solids. Outcomes from this project will find their applications in many areas beside batteries, such as solid oxide fuel cells, solid oxide electrolysis cells, gas separation membrane, high temperature resonant sensors, nanocrystalline components, micromachining of semiconductors, etc.
